Martin, 28, have been traveling the country talking about their recent books about young women and also as part of an intergenerational conversation series with the name: WomenGirlsLadies: A Fresh Conversation Across Generations. (The name is adapted from an old country western song—“There’s girls and there’s women and there’s ladies. There’s yeses, there’s nos, and there’s maybes”— and includes author/activists Gloria Feldt – and Kristal Brent Zook as well.)

abstract: Peak Gold, owner of the Amapari mine in Brazil, agreed to a $1.6 billion all-stock combination with Metallica Resources and New Gold to diversify and increase production.
snippet: Peak Gold, owner of the Amapari mine in Brazil, agreed to a $1.6 billion all-stock combination with Metallica Resources and New Gold to diversify and increase production.
lead_paragraph: Peak Gold, owner of the Amapari mine in Brazil, agreed to a $1.6 billion all-stock combination with Metallica Resources and New Gold to diversify and increase production. The combined company, to be called New Gold, is expected to produce 297,000 ounces of gold this year and 335,000 ounces in 2009 from operations in Australia, Brazil and Mexico, Peak said. Shareholders in Peak, which is based in Vancouver, will receive 0.1 New Gold share for each Peak share they own. Investors in Metallica, based in Toronto, will receive 0.9 New Gold share for each share in the company.

headline.main: Canada: Mining Companies in a Merger

snippet: ABC is preparing an unscripted series called “I Survived A Japanese Game Show.” Which understandably leads us to wonder: what exactly is a “Japanese game show” and why is it so perilous?
lead_paragraph: Game shows run the gamut, from those that treat contestants respectfully and require some demonstrable skills (think “Jeopardy” or “Wheel of Fortune”) to those that aim to humiliate or embarrass (perhaps “Weakest Link” and definitely “Moment of Truth”). Now a slightly new genre is coming to America: the Japanese game show, which seems to combine elements of “American Gladiator” with old-time stunt shows like “Beat the Clock.”

headline.main: The Latest Japanese Imports: Game Shows

The participants on the Sunday night call, who got a preview of the deal, were Wall Street’s biggest power brokers: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs dialed in from home. John Mack of Morgan Stanley rushed to the office to listen on speakerphone. Richard Fuld of Lehman Brothers, who had been directed to return home from a business trip in New Delhi by none other than Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, was patched in, too, among others.

lead_paragraph: It seems that some lawmakers in Washington have been listening to all our talk about the disastrous situation around health insurance for small businesses and the self-employed. On Wednesday, a bipartisan group of senators — Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine; Dick Durbin, the majority whip who is a Democrat from Illinois; Blanche Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas; and Norm Coleman, Republican of Minnesota — proposed legislation that seeks to reduce the cost and improve coverage options for small businesses. The bill is supported by the National Federation of Independent Businesses, the National Association of Realtors and the Service Employees International Union.

headline.main: Some Hope on the Health Insurance Front

abstract: Sodexo said first-half sales rose 3.8 percent, to 7.08 billion euros ($11 billion) in the six months through February from 6.82 billion euros a year earlier.
snippet: Sodexo said first-half sales rose 3.8 percent, to 7.08 billion euros ($11 billion) in the six months through February from 6.82 billion euros a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Sodexo, the catering company, said first-half sales rose 3.8 percent, to 7.08 billion euros ($11 billion) in the six months through February from 6.82 billion euros a year earlier. Sodexo said North American sales, which make up two-fifths of overall revenue, climbed 5.8 percent, excluding acquisitions and currency movements. Revenue rose 8 percent in Continental Europe excluding takeovers and exchange rates. British and Irish sales gained 22 percent on that basis. The company said sales were helped by bookings it handled for the rugby World Cup.

headline.main: France: Sales Up 3.8%. For Caterer
headline.print_headline: France: Sales Up 3.8%. For Caterer

lead_paragraph: From the first moment I logged onto CompuServe, I’ve been in love with the potential of online services to turbocharge comparison shopping by combing through all the options to find the very best deals. This is a mindset, I’ve discovered, that I share with many engineers and technically minded business people who also see shopping as a great optimization equation. And I’ve spent many hours talking with excited idealist entrepreneurs who have just started companies that are meant to empower consumers in some market or another. Tonny Yu of ComputerESP, Farhad Mohit of BizRate and Doug Lebda of LendingTree, are just some that come to mind.

headline.main: Zillow and the Idealism of Engineers Going Shopping

lead_paragraph: I DUCKED into the New York International Table Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens, puzzling over the peculiar sound echoing in my ears. With preposterously high odds against me, I was going to play a challenge game of what is commonly known as Ping-Pong. But the echoing I heard did not match that supposedly onomatopoeic name. Instead, it sounded more like a dozen clocks synchronized to the staccato beat of tock-tock-tock-tock.

headline.main: Ping-Pong as Mind Game (Although a Good Topspin Helps)

lead_paragraph: INDECENCY APPEAL REJECTED  The News Corporation’s appeal of $91,000 in indecency fines for a 2003 broadcast featuring strippers at bachelor and bachelorette parties has been rejected by the Federal Communications Commission on technical grounds. The appeal from the Fox Television unit exceeded a 25-page limit for responses, the agency said Friday in an order posted on its Web site. The F.C.C. said in the three-paragraph order that the fines would stand because Fox neither complied with the rule nor sought a waiver. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: Vacancies at community and neighborhood shopping centers in the United States rose in the first quarter to the highest level in more than a decade.
snippet: Vacancies at community and neighborhood shopping centers in the United States rose in the first quarter to the highest level in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: VACANT SHOPPING CENTERS Vacancies at community and neighborhood shopping centers in the United States rose in the first quarter to the highest level in more than a decade, and rent growth was the lowest since the last recession, the research firm Reis reported on Friday. The average vacancy rate rose to 7.7 percent from 7.1 percent a year earlier. It was the highest since 1996, the real-estate researcher said. Demand for retail space is being hurt by a drop in home prices and sales, rising food and gasoline costs, and job cuts, Reis said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline.main: Vacant Shopping Centers

headline.main: Yahoo’s Big Question: Is Steve Ballmer Bluffing?

abstract: The corporate love of buying back stock — which Wall Street encourages as much as it can — reached new heights late last year. Standard & Poor’s, which has been tracking buyback data for the S.&P. 500 since 1998, reports that in the fourth quarter of last year, companies in the index had net reported profits of $68 billion — and spent $141 billion buying back stock. That was the first quarter in which the companies managed to spend double their net income in buybacks. The third quarter of 2007 had been the first time that buybacks exceeded profits for the companies.

abstract: Dan Pink’s latest book delivers career advice in the Japanese comic format known as manga.
snippet: Dan Pink’s latest book delivers career advice in the Japanese comic format known as manga.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I interviewed Dan Pink, fresh off a two month stay in Japan, where he had immersed himself in the study of manga, a Japanese form of print cartoons and a $2.4 billion -a-year publishing niche. In Japan manga books cover a wide range of topics — from retirement to sexuality — and they are read by people of all ages. Mr. Pink studied manga while in Tokyo on a fellowship sponsored by the Japan Society. Once he got home, he applied his newfound expertise to publish the first manga business book for the American market, The Adventures of Johnny Bunko: The Last Career Guide You’ll Ever Need.

headline.main: Career Advice for the Short Attention Span

abstract: The Baugur Group will sell its media, technology and financial units for £430 million ($852 million) and use the funds to expand in retail.
snippet: The Baugur Group will sell its media, technology and financial units for £430 million ($852 million) and use the funds to expand in retail.
lead_paragraph: The Baugur Group, the Icelandic owner of the House of Fraser department stores in Britain, will sell its media, technology and financial units for £430 million ($852 million) and use the funds to expand in retail. Assets including a property investor, the FL Group; and Saga Film and EFG, a cinema producer, will be sold to two independent companies led by Baugur directors, the company said. Baugur investments including Saga, the media company 365 and Teymi, which offers information-technology services, will be sold to Stodir Invest, while financial assets like FL will go to Styrkur Invest. Baugur is based in Reykjavik.

headline.main: Iceland: A Retailer Plans to Shed Units

lead_paragraph: American Airlines, the airline owned by the AMR Corporation, said late Tuesday that it expected to cancel as many as 500 flights  more than a fifth of its daily total  to reinspect its fleet of 300 MD-80 jetliners to make sure a wiring bundle in the wheel wells was stowed properly.

headline.main: American Canceling More Flights for Inspection
headline.print_headline: American Cancels Flights To Allow a Reinspection

abstract: BP and ConocoPhillips joined forces to try to develop Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas, saying they would spend billions to build a North Slope pipeline.
snippet: BP and ConocoPhillips joined forces to try to develop Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas, saying they would spend billions to build a North Slope pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Two of the world’s biggest oil companies, BP and ConocoPhillips, joined forces Tuesday to try to break a longstanding deadlock over Alaska’s vast reserves of natural gas. They said they would spend billions to build a pipeline from the North Slope to feed energy-hungry markets in the United States and Canada.

headline.main: 2 Oil Firms Plan Alaska Gas Pipeline

abstract: Prosecutors claim the man, Steven Goodwin is a mastermind behind the collapse of Capetown-based Fidentia Asset Management.
snippet: Prosecutors claim the man, Steven Goodwin is a mastermind behind the collapse of Capetown-based Fidentia Asset Management.
lead_paragraph: Steven Goodwin, who prosecutors claim is a mastermind behind the collapse of Fidentia Asset Management, a money manager based in Cape Town, was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport after arriving from Australia. South Africa will seek to extradite Mr. Goodwin, whose arrest was confirmed by prosecutors in the United States, and charge him with theft, fraud and corruption, the National Prosecuting Authority in Pretoria said. Fidentia was placed under administration last February, accused of stealing client funds, with losses estimated at as much as 1 billion rand ($130 million). An investigation found that the company had invested in private equity ventures outside the mandate given by investors and its license conditions, and that client funds had been used to pay for the personal expenses of its chairman, Arthur Brown. Mr. Brown, who has denied wrongdoing, is to face trial by Oct. 3, the South African Press Association reported last month. The company’s accountant, Graham Maddock, was sentenced to a seven-year term under a plea deal, the news agency said.

headline.main: South Africa: Fugitive Arrested in Los Angeles
headline.print_headline: South Africa: Fugitive Arrested In Los Angeles

abstract: Leon Black generally avoids the public eye — so why did his buyout firm, Apollo Management, just file to go public? And why now, when private equity deals are in a credit-crunch-induced coma? Well, it had to: As part of its debut last August on Goldman Sachs‘s private market, GSTrUE, Apollo agreed to register for a public offering in 240 days. The deadline was just about now. Like it or not, it’s showtime.

lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex.  Among the jobs little boys dream of  policeman, fireman, bulldozer driver  airline pilot long held the added virtue of satisfying grown-up dreams: pay that reached $300,000 a year, 20 days a month off work, the prestige of one day commanding a $200 million airplane, and a lush retirement at 60.

headline.main: For Pilots, Dreams Run Into Reality
headline.print_headline: Dreams Fly Into Reality

abstract: Gazprom of Russia, the natural gas producer, and Eni of Italy are preparing to join forces to pipe natural gas from Libya across the Mediterranean to Southern Europe. The deal would enable Russia to increase Europe’s dependence on Gazprom, which is state controlled. Paolo Scaroni, left, chief executive of Eni, said the deal with Gazprom would involve “the swap of assets outside of Russia.” Russia already supplies more than a quarter of Western Europe’s energy needs. Some analysts said that if Gazprom succeeded in Libya and in Algeria, where it is competing for contracts, it could end up dominating the supply routes to Southern Europe.

abstract: Bell Canada received the final regulatory approval for its acquisition by a private investment group led by a branch of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan and valued at about 52 billion Canadian dollars. Industry Canada, the government department responsible for radio frequencies used by mobile phone networks, approved the sale provided that the new owners document changes that will ensure Canadian control of the company. Two issues still stand in the way of the deal’s scheduled closing at the end of June. An appeals court in Quebec must hear a challenge to the transaction raised by some bondholders. More important, the financing for the transaction must be completed. Ontario Teachers’ has repeatedly dismissed speculation by some investors that credit market turmoil may cause banks to back away from their lending commitments.

abstract: The chief executive of the French bank Société Générale said it expected to spend up to 100 million euros this year to improve its risk-management systems.

lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the French bank Société Générale said it expected to spend up to 100 million euros this year to improve its risk-management systems after a trading scandal that resulted in nearly 5 billion euros in losses. Yet he cautioned that the additional investment could never fully guarantee against frauds. “Fraud has existed for as long as banks have existed,” the executive, Daniel Bouton, told members of the French Parliament’s finance committee. “There have been several fraud cases, and there will be others.”

abstract: After months of nearly total silence, the chief executive of the EADSC has begun a counteroffensive against accusations of rampant insider trading.

lead_paragraph: After months of nearly total silence, the chief executive of the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company has begun a counteroffensive against accusations by French regulators of rampant insider trading among senior managers at the aerospace group and its Airbus subsidiary, suggesting that the regulators did not understand the intricacy of the aircraft business. In interviews published in two leading French and German newspapers, the executive, Louis Gallois, above, challenged assertions by the Autorité des Marchés Financiers that information held by 17 senior managers at Airbus and at EADS who sold shares in November 2005 or March 2006 had been privileged or market-sensitive. And in a 10-page document sent to the agency, he pointedly attacked its case, calling it “entirely unfounded, both in fact and in law.”

headline.main: France: Chief of EADS Speaks Out
headline.print_headline: FRANCE: CHIEF OF EADS SPEAKS OUT

abstract: Lukoil, the Russian oil company, has decided to sell 162 of the more than 1,800 gas stations it owns in the United States because the sites, in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, are less profitable than other Lukoil investments, the company said. Some of the stations, acquired from ConocoPhillips, were still changing their brand names and it was unclear which brand they would carry after the sale, according to Lukoil's press service in Moscow. Lukoil operates stations under the Lukoil and Getty brands in 13 Northeastern states.

Lukoil operates stations under the Lukoil and Getty brands in 13 Northeastern states.

abstract: American Airlines became the last of the major network carriers to join in a new across-the-board fare increase.
snippet: American Airlines became the last of the major network carriers to join in a new across-the-board fare increase.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN JOINS FARE INCREASE  Ending a week in which it abruptly canceled more than 3,000 flights for maintenance inspections, American Airlines became the last of the major network carriers to join in a new across-the-board fare increase. The latest round of increases, the seventh involving fares or fuel surcharges this year, was started by United Airlines last week and then matched by the other five network carriers, said Tom Parsons of BestFares.com. The successive fare increases and fuel charges have added a total of “up to $170 round-trip” to many tickets, Mr. Parsons said. Rick Seaney, of FareCompare.com, said that fuel surcharges alone now average $50 a ticket for domestic travel, $215 for European travel and $280 for travel to Asia. Jet fuel on the spot market was $3.56 a gallon last week, compared with $1.39 a gallon in January 2005, he said.

headline.main: Memo Pad
headline.print_headline: Memo Pad

abstract: Riots erupted when members of a shadowy sect blockaded roads to protest the killing of their leader’s wife. Members of the notorious Mungiki gang, a cultlike organization that runs extortion rings across Kenya, attacked commuters and fought the police in several towns. Local news reports indicated that as many as 12 people might have been killed, but Kenyan police officials said they had no confirmation of any deaths. Virginia Nyakio, the Mungiki leader’s wife, was found dead last week with her throat slit in a forest outside Nairobi.

abstract: Air-traffic controllers respond to David Pogue’s recent coverage of the ADS-B air-traffic control system the Federal Aviation Administration will install by 2020.
snippet: Air-traffic controllers respond to David Pogue’s recent coverage of the ADS-B air-traffic control system the Federal Aviation Administration will install by 2020.
lead_paragraph: Last week in this space, I offered an excerpt from my CBS News interview with Robert Sturgell, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, about the new ADS-B air-traffic control system that the agency will install by 2020, at a cost of $20 billion. It's a GPS-based system that would replace or supplement our 50-year-old, hopelessly overstressed radar system. It's the core of an even larger air-traffic overhaul nicknamed NextGen.

headline.main: The Costs of Solving the Air-Traffic Mess
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: When it comes to social networking, it is acceptable to be a workplace flirt.
snippet: When it comes to social networking, it is acceptable to be a workplace flirt.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of online dating, there is an awkward moment in which one party removes his or her profile before the other. By “delisting,” the removing party is basically saying that she (or he) is no longer looking. Interestingly, the way the delisting party figures this out is by logging onto the site and looking, which raises the issue of whether the other half of the couple is, in fact, completely not looking.

abstract: Customer behavior toward keeping up satellite-radio subscriptions depends on whether they have sought out the service or received it as a promotion.
snippet: Customer behavior toward keeping up satellite-radio subscriptions depends on whether they have sought out the service or received it as a promotion.
lead_paragraph: When satellite-radio customers are asked whether they will keep their subscriptions through the end of the year, they answer differently depending on whether they have sought out the service or received it free through radios already installed in new or leased cars. People in the latter group, by 26 percentage points, are less likely to say they will “absolutely keep” the service, according to a questionnaire answered by about 3,510 users who also listen to AM/FM stations, and prepared by Jacobs Media, a consultancy for broadcast radio.

headline.main: Staying in the Orbit of Satellite Radio

abstract: With its eighth and final episode of the season, “Oprah’s Big Give” earned a modest audience of 10 million viewers on Sunday, down from earlier this season but enough to help lift ABC to No. 1 on the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality charity competition has seen its ratings decline steadily after drawing 15.7 million viewers in its debut on March 2. Still, the finale managed to dominate its 8 p.m. time slot ahead of CBS’s “Big Brother” (6.8 million) and NBC’s “Monk” (5.7 million).

abstract: After bouts with debilitating illnesses, one women turns her experience into a way to help others, and to earn a living.
snippet: After bouts with debilitating illnesses, one women turns her experience into a way to help others, and to earn a living.
lead_paragraph: In researching my column on how small business owners deal with health insurance, I talked to Rosalind Joffe, an executivecoach who specializes in helping people who have chronic illnesses. Ms. Joffe has suffered from multiple sclerosis and ulcerative colitis, both of which have stabilized with treatment — the removal of her colon for the colitis, and the medication, Avonex, for her MS. Prior to getting sick, Ms. Joffe had two successful careers, first as a multimedia producer and then as a professor of communications at Boston University. She became a coach because she wanted a job that she could do from home and that would be flexible enough to allow her to modify her schedule whenever she had a bad day. She credits her ability to make that career change to the fact that her husband had a good health insurance policy that could cover her as well — yet another example of health insurance affecting a career choice.

headline.main: Working While Chronically Ill

abstract: First Quantum Minerals, a Canadian miner of copper in Zambia and Congo, agreed to buy Scandinavian Minerals for about 281 million Canadian dollars ($280 million) to add a nickel mine in Finland. Scandinavian Minerals investors will receive 9 Canadian dollars in cash and 0.01 of a common share of First Quantum for each share they hold, First Quantum said. The offer values Scandinavian Minerals at 41 percent higher than its April 18 closing price. The transaction will give First Quantum, which is based in Vancouver, full control of the Kevitsa property in northern Finland, which has as much as 831 million metric tons of nickel-ore resources on an indicated and inferred basis, according to Scandinavian Minerals.

abstract: The Ford Motor Company will add 1,500 workers at a Russian factory to increase production in that country by almost 75 percent, the company said. Ford plans to increase capacity at the Vsevolozhsk plant near St. Petersburg to 125,000 vehicles next year, a spokeswoman in Moscow, Ekaterina Kulinenko, said. The factory produces the Focus hatchback, Russia’s best-selling foreign-brand car in 2007, and will start making the midsize Mondeo this year, Ms. Kulinenko said.

abstract: A former executive with Wal-Mart, Allan Leighton, became president of Canada’s largest grocery retailer, the Loblaw Companies, on Monday. Once known for its innovation, Loblaw has stumbled recently as the company deals with Wal-Mart Canada’s gradual move into the grocery business. Mr. Leighton, left, was the chief executive of Asda Stores, a British supermarket chain, when it was acquired by Wal-Mart in 1996. He was subsequently made president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Europe and later became nonexecutive chairman of the Royal Mail of Britain. The Weston family of Toronto, who control Loblaw as well as several businesses in Britain, brought Mr. Leighton to the Canadian chain as deputy chairman in 2006, a position he will retain. Mark Foote, the company’s president and chief merchandising officer, has left Loblaw, the company said, as has Pietro Satriano, its executive vice president for food.

abstract: An article on April 10 about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misspelled part of the name of the firm for which L. Nick Lacey, a former director of flight standards at the Federal Aviation Administration, now works. And a correction in this space on Wednesday rendered the firm’s name incorrectly and misidentified the nature of its business. It is Morten Beyer & Agnew  not Morton, Beyer & Agnew  and it is an airline consulting firm, not a law firm. (The name contains no comma. Morten Beyer is a senior adviser in the firm, not the surnames of two associates.)
lead_paragraph: An article on April 10 about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misspelled part of the name of the firm for which L. lead_paragraph: The Bank of Canada reduced its benchmark lending rate by one half of a percentage point, bringing it to 3 percent. It was the second consecutive cut in the rate and its announcement came with a warning about deteriorating economic conditions in the United States. “The bank is now projecting a deeper and more protracted slowdown in the U.S. economy,” it said. “This has direct consequences for the Canadian economic outlook, with declining exports projected to exert a significant drag on growth in 2008.” The central bank added that it did not expect the economy of the United States to stabilize until the middle of 2010.

headline.main: Canada: Central Bank Reduces Lending Rate

abstract: British regulators said BAA’s near monopoly of the busiest airport markets in the country was restricting competition.
snippet: British regulators said BAA’s near monopoly of the busiest airport markets in the country was restricting competition.
lead_paragraph: BAA, the airport operator, may be forced to sell terminals in England and Scotland after British regulators said its near monopoly of the busiest airport markets in the country was restricting competition. In a report, the Competition Commission said BAA’s dominance of the airport markets in southeast England and central Scotland limited choices for passengers and airlines and curbed the expansion of capacity. Colin Matthews, BAA’s chief executive, said the company would address the commission’s concerns but did not agree that selling terminals would improve service.

headline.main: Britain: Sales of Airport Terminals Suggested
headline.print_headline: BRITAIN: SALES OF AIRPORT TERMINALS SUGGESTED

abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland became the latest lender to seek new funds to cover its soured investments, saying it would sell $23.8 billion of new shares to investors.
snippet: The Royal Bank of Scotland became the latest lender to seek new funds to cover its soured investments, saying it would sell $23.8 billion of new shares to investors.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland became the latest lender to seek new funds to cover its soured investments, saying it would sell $23.8 billion of new shares to current investors as it seeks to restore its capital base. Royal Bank said it was writing down £5.9 billion ($11.7 billion) in assets this year. Investors can obtain 11 new shares for every 18 shares they own at 200 pence a share, a 46 percent discount from the bank’s closing share price of 372 pence a share on Monday. Royal Bank is seeking to raise an additional $7.9 billion through the disposal of assets.

headline.main: Britain: Royal Bank of Scotland Raises Capital
headline.print_headline: BRITAIN: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND RAISES CAPITAL

abstract: After hearing testimony from patients whose vision was impaired by laser surgery, a Food and Drug Administration panel said Friday that the agency should do a better job informing patients of the surgery’s risks.
snippet: After hearing testimony from patients whose vision was impaired by laser surgery, a Food and Drug Administration panel said Friday that the agency should do a better job informing patients of the surgery’s risks.
lead_paragraph: After hearing testimony from patients whose vision was impaired by laser surgery, a Food and Drug Administration panel said Friday that the agency should do a better job informing patients of the surgery’s risks. It also recommended that a system that reports adverse medical incidents associated with laser vision surgery include data about poor quality of vision, to encompass the visual “glares,” “starbursts,” and “halos” commonly reported by patients with negative experiences. The F.D.A. recently recruited the National Eye Institute to study how patients’ quality of life has been affected by laser eye surgery.

headline.main: F.D.A. Panel Urges More Data on Laser Vision Surgery
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Panel Urges More Data On Laser Vision Surgery

abstract: In looking for a financial adviser, one thing to ask is if they have fiduciary duty, which means they will have to put your interests ahead of theirs at all times when providing investment advice.
snippet: In looking for a financial adviser, one thing to ask is if they have fiduciary duty, which means they will have to put your interests ahead of theirs at all times when providing investment advice.
lead_paragraph: LIKE many people, especially in these financially unsettling times, I long for someone to look at our portfolio  such as it is  and tell us how to manage everything so that we can send both our children to the college of their choice, retire at 65 and be able to send postcards from exotic locations to our future grandchildren.

headline.main: Pick a Planner Who Can Spell ‘Fiduciary’
headline.print_headline: Pick a Planner Who Can Spell ‘Fiduciary’

abstract: Daniel L. Sparks, head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage division, is leaving after a successful bet on the declining value of subprime home loans helped the company produce record earnings last year.
snippet: Daniel L. Sparks, head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage division, is leaving after a successful bet on the declining value of subprime home loans helped the company produce record earnings last year.
lead_paragraph: Daniel L. Sparks, head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage division, is leaving after a successful bet on the declining value of subprime home loans helped the company produce record earnings last year. Michael DuVally, a spokesman at Goldman, did not provide a reason for the departure and Mr. Sparks, 41, declined to comment. Mr. Sparks, who has been at Goldman Sachs for 19 years, is the second executive to depart from a Goldman team that reaped profits from the collapse of the subprime mortgage market while rival firms racked up losses. Josh Birnbaum, a trader, left earlier this month and plans to form a $1 billion hedge fund.

headline.main: Top Mortgage Executive Is Leaving Goldman Sachs

lead_paragraph: Last Thursday night at 6:30 p.m., I joined a group of female entrepreneurs determined to learn the secrets of eliminating stress from our lives. It was smack in the middle of rush hour and few of us arrived right on schedule. The remainder trickled in over the next half hour, with each latecomer exuding a look that said, “My life is so busy that it is hard to be punctual even for a destressing workshop.” We filed into the conference room at In Good Company Workplaces and then Jennifer Edwards, a “stress reduction educator” with a background in dance, meditation and yoga, asked us to go around the table introducing ourselves along with a statement about why we think we were all so stressed. It went something like this:

abstract: Romano Prodi, Italy’s departing prime minister, declined an offer from Russia’s Gazprom to become chairman of a new Russian-Italian natural gas pipeline.
snippet: Romano Prodi, Italy’s departing prime minister, declined an offer from Russia’s Gazprom to become chairman of a new Russian-Italian natural gas pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Romano Prodi, Italy’s departing prime minister, declined an offer from Gazprom, the Russian energy company, to become chairman of a new Russian-Italian natural gas pipeline. Aleksei Miller, Gazprom’s chief executive, made the offer in Rome where he met with Mr. Prodi and executives at its partner in the project, the Italian energy group Eni. Analysts said Gazprom’s attempts to entice Mr. Prodi to the project showed its determination to match its ever-growing energy power in Europe with political influence. Once complete, the pipeline, running under the Black Sea, would have a capacity of about 1 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year, according to Gazprom and Eni. Gazprom is also building a pipeline beneath the Baltic Sea to ship natural gas to Germany.

headline.main: Italy: Ex-Premier Declines Russian Energy Job

abstract: American Airlines plans to join the competition May 12 and start charging $25 for a second checked bag.
snippet: American Airlines plans to join the competition May 12 and start charging $25 for a second checked bag.
lead_paragraph: MORE CHECKED-BAG FEES The lone holdout among the network carriers, American Airlines, said Monday that on May 12 it would join the competition and start charging $25 for a second checked bag. The fee will apply to all coach passengers except those on full-fare tickets and those with elite status in the AAdvantage frequent-flier program. The Alaska Air Group, which operates Alaska Airlines and Horizon Air, said it would also start charging $25 for a second checked bag, starting this summer. The fee for an overweight bag will double, to $50, and the extra fee for an unaccompanied minor will rise to $75 from $30. Horizon Air, meanwhile, will get rid of 20 CRJ-700 regional jets as part of a plan to fly only 76-seat Bombardier Q400 turbo-propeller planes. The CRJ-700s are less fuel-efficient.

headline.main: More Checked Bag Fees in Coach

lead_paragraph: A German mobile phone company, Freenet, agreed to buy a rival, Debitel, for 1.63 billion euros ($2.5 billion), forming Germany’s third-largest mobile phone company and fending off a takeover from United Internet. Freenet will acquire Debitel from a buyout firm, Permira Advisers, it said. Freenet will issue 32 million new shares to give Permira a 24.99 percent stake in the merged company and receive a loan of 132.5 million euros from the buyout firm. United Internet, Germany’s second-largest Web provider, after Deutsche Telekom, made a tentative bid of 16 euros a share for Freenet, which is based in Büdelsdorf, but said it was no longer interested in acquiring the company.

headline.main: Germany: Internet Provider Acquired

abstract: As the credit markets have seized up, some on Wall Street have drawn a line from the current crisis back to Michael R. Milken, once known as the “junk bond king” of Drexel Burnham Lambert. But did the junk bond and the slicing and dicing of debt — both of which Mr. Milken clearly helped popularize — lead to the mess we are in today? Absolutely not, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times. Such criticism is akin to blaming the inventor of paper money, he says.

And if the prospect of a belt-straining flight isn’t too alarming, there’s a Valrhona chocolate fondue with bananas, marshmallows and waffles for dessert. Three courses cost about £32  or $64  before wine or tip.

headline.main: BA Confirms Talks With American, Continental

abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “Nielsen is moving the February 2009 sweeps to March to avoid the ‘potential disruptions’ associated with the switch to digital. It will also begin testing ratings collection on digital-only stations in December 2008.”

headline.main: February Sweep Becomes March Sweep In ’09
